ymp_slice.ymp_txt: How can we determine final concentrations for equilibrium systems? In order to determine steady state concentrations in a chemical solution, we need to know 1) the initial concentrations of chemical species, 2) the chemical equation for the chemical reaction, and 3) the value of the equilibrium constant, K.

Reversible reactions reach chemical equilibrium when the reaction quotient, Q, is equal to the equilibrium constant, K. We will use the fact that Q = K at equilibrium to predict equilibrium concentrations.
In this example the solution has the given concentrations and undergoes the reaction described by the chemical equation, for which the equilibrium constant, K, is 19.

The reaction is reversible, meaning both the forward and reverse reaction occur simultaneously. At equilibrium, the rates of the forward and reverse reaction become equal and the concentrations of the chemical species reach a steady state. Equilibrium is reached when Q = K, where Q for this reaction is the ratio shown here.

As the reaction progresses, it "shifts" along a continuum of possible states. Our initial concentrations correspond to Q=0.055. This is considerably smaller than the equilibrium constant, K=19. The reaction will therefore shift towards product. As the concentration of product increases and reactants decrease Q will towards 19.

The change in concentrations must obey the stoichiometry of the reaction. When the concetrations change as shown here the resulting concentrations lead to Q=1.0. Although Q has increased, it remains less than 19, the value of K.
When concentrations change by an additional 40%, the resulting Q is 33. Q is now greater than K=19. This describes a state of the reaction that has shifted too far toward the product.
Given the initial conditions, the reaction will progress from the initial position towards product until Q=K, a state which lies between the two trial changes listed here.
To determine the precise change in concentrations needed for Q to equal K, one approach is to introduce a variable x that describes the change.

A single variable, x, suffices because the changes in concentrations must obey the stoichiometry of the reaction. The change in reactants and products must have opposite sign. A shift in the forward direction will decrease the reactant concentrations and increase the product concentrations. Similarly, a shift in the reverse direction increases the reactant concentrations and decreases the product concentrations. Since we determined that our initial Q is less than K, we put a negative sign in front of the variable x for the reactants. We ensure the changes obey stoichiometry by multiplying the variable x by the stoichiometric coefficients of the reaction. In this case, the (-2x) for L means that the change in [L] is twice that in [Fe+3] and [FeL2+3].
The resulting concentrations are obtained by subtracting or adding the change from the initial concentrations. We can then insert the resulting concentrations into the Q formula for this reaction.

Our expression for Q is now a function of a single variable x. This expression describes the range of possible states of the chemical reaction. Our above two trial changes correspond to x=1.0 and x=1.4. Although we could continue to make guesses at x until we find a value at which Q=K, it is more efficient to solve Q=K for x algebraically.
Our goal is to find the value of x for which Q=K, since this will give us the change in concentrations needed to reach the equilibrium steady state.
To solve algebraically for x, we begin by expanding the denominator.
We then cross multiply and combine terms to get a cubic polynomial equation.

A cubic polynomial has three roots, meaning there are three values for x that will cause this cubic polynomial to be zero. You can obtain these using a modern calculator. (Please see the manual for your calculator.) Or by using the following website: http://www.1728.com/cubic.htm The results are shown here.

All chemical systems we will consider have a single unique equilibrium state. There will always only be one root that gives reasonable results, i.e. that leads to all concentrations having positive values.

We'll try each of the roots in turn by plugging the value for x into our results line for each species. For the first root, we can get the changes in concentrations, and the resulting concentrations, by putting x= 3.987 into our table. This root leads to [L] being negative. Since negative concentrations are impossible, we can reject this solution.

The second root also leads to a negative [L], and can also be rejected. Although these concentrations obey the Q=K equilibrium condition, we can reject this solution since it leads to a negative concentration.

The third value for x leads to positive concentrations for all chemical species and is a valid solution. In the table, we have replaced the "result" label with "equilibrium", since these concentrations correspond to equilibrium concentrations.
Tables of this type are often called ICE tables due to the Initial, Change, Equilibrium notation.

Although all three roots lead to concentrations for which Q=K, only x=1.370 leads to positive concentrations. So we now know that the equilibrium concentrations are those corresponding to this value of x, which are listed here.

Since we've done a lot of algebra above, it is a good idea to check our answer. A useful check is to confirm that our equilibrium concentrations obey Q=K. Our concentrations pass this test. If they did not, we could go back and check our calculations to find where we went wrong.
